intro: Crocus albocoronatus, commonly known as the white-crowned crocus, is a member of the Iridaceae family and is native to the Mediterranean region. It is a perennial herb that typically grows to a height of 10–20 cm, featuring narrow, grass-like leaves. The plant produces showy, cup-shaped flowers with white petals and a yellow center, blooming in early spring. It thrives in well-drained soil and partial shade, often found in rocky or gravelly habitats. Due to its ornamental value and rarity, it is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens.
